**Expense Tracker \- Continuous Integration and Continuous Deployment Pipeline** 

**Need of CI/CD Pipeline:**

It is important to have a CI/CD pipeline for our Expense Tracker project because it automates the process of testing, integrating and building code with each push and pull request to the main branch. This continuous integration ensures that every change is checked and validated thoroughly before it goes into production, so that we have a bug-free, secure code-base. By automating these processes:

* We can ensure that every developer contributes high-quality, formatted and well-tested code that meets the coding standards of the project and is free from security vulnerabilities.  
* The pipeline can run automated security scans(Codacy), further reducing the risk of potential hacking.  
* It helps in identifying bugs early in the development cycle, enabling us to address issues before the users notice them, or they become larger problems.  
* The pipeline saves us valuable time by automating repetitive tasks like testing and later deployment.

As a result, our team can focus on building new features and improving the application, leading to a faster and more reliable development process.

**Steps of our CI/CD Pipeline(Currently Functional):**

Our CI/CD pipeline runs in a sequential format rather than a parallel format, so that the risk of dependencies from other steps does not occur. The steps in this sequential process are depicted in Figure 1\. We begin by checking the formatting of the code using linting and formatting tools. Next, we run tests to ensure the functionality of the code. After that, we evaluate code quality using Codacy. Finally, we generate documentation with JSDoc and store it as an artifact in the last step. In addition to these automated steps, we also have a human review after all the steps have completed, providing a final check before the pull request is merged into the main branch.

![Figure 1](cicd.drawio.png)

Figure 1 \- Expense Tracker Project’s CICD Pipeline

**Lint and Format:**

The first step in our CI/CD pipeline is to ensure that the code follows proper coding standards. According to our coding standards file, all code should be formatted using Prettier and free of syntactical and code mistakes. This is checked by using linting tools that check for common mistakes, like incorrect indentations and variables. At the same time, we apply formatting to ensure that the code is consistent in style across the entire project. This makes the code easier to read and maintain, and helps prevent simple issues that could lead to bugs later on.

**Test:**

After ensuring the code style is correct, we move on to running tests. The jest and selenium tests we write for our project are automatically run in this step. They cover different scenarios, ensuring that all the features function correctly and that new changes don’t break any existing functionality. This step helps us catch errors early and ensures the stability of the codebase.

**Code-Quality (Codacy):**

Next, we run a code quality analysis using a tool called Codacy. We have integrated Codacy in our project using the correct security measures and API secret token. Codacy checks the code for various issues, including code complexity, potential bugs, **security vulnerabilities**, and adherence to best practices**. Even though this is an extra integration, it is well worth it to ensure our code-base cannot be hacked.** This step helps us improve the overall quality of the code and ensures that it remains clean, efficient, and secure as the project grows.

**JSDocs:**

After Codacy analyzes the code quality, we need to document the code we have written. This is done via JSDocs which generates documentation directly from comments in the code and stores it as an artifact in the workflow pipeline. This can help other developers accessing the code to understand what it means and why it was written. It improves collaboration, understanding and documentation.

**Code-Quality (Human Review):**

Finally, after all the automated checks are complete, one of our admins/team-leads goes through the code. This step is crucial because automated tools may miss context-specific issues or design concerns that a developer would catch. The admin/team-lead checks the overall logic of the code to ensure that it meets the project's standards before it is merged into the main branch. This manual review is the last line of defense against potential issues, ensuring that the code is functional and logical.

**Future Planned Additions:**

In the future, we plan to add an automated deployment step to our CI/CD pipeline, so that we can automatically deploy our code to the production website/app as soon as all the automated CI steps and human code review are complete. This will help in reducing human errors in deployment and fast delivery of new features and bug fixes.
